bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Henry Rose Carter, December 13, 1900

div1.p: Reed's experiments have convinced Gorgas that the mosquito theory is valid. Gorgas discusses the implications for sanitation and non-immune troops.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Henry Rose Carter, December 13, 1900
div1.opener:
Headquarters Department of Cuba.
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER OF HAVANA
Havana, Cuba,December 13, 1900
LA MAESTRANZA
CALLE DE CUBA
ENTRE CUARTELES Y CHACON
Dr. H. R. Carter,
Marine-Hospital Service,
Baltimore, Md.. My Dear Carter,-
div1.p:
Yours of November 24th received. Am so much pleased at the
news you give of your general health. While I have been pretty cer-
tain that you had no serious cerebral organic lesion, I have been anx-
ious to hear the opinion of such men as Osl or other equally good
diagnosticians on the case. If it were possible, I think it would be
a great thing for you and for the corps, for you to return to Havana and
help us out. It seems to me we are on the high road toward revolu-
tionizing sanitation, as far as yellow fever is concerned. Your ex-
perienced & skill on this subject, would be most valuable down here.
Why could you not be attached for work in connection with yellow fever,
and just be given a free lance? Have nothing to do with the Marine-
Hospital work proper, of Havana; just act as a member of the Board and
have a finger in the pie generally. I think it is a waste of time, and
more than one man can do, for you to attempt to work as you did last
summer. The Marine-Hospital work (excuse me for saying it) is unim-
portant compared to the yellow fever work and the same man cannot at-
tend to both.

Ross is has about concludinged the contract and L- joins us, and we are
whetting our swords and patching our badly dilapidated armor for next
summer's work.

I think yellow fever is about over for the season. We have
this morning twenty six cases under treatment, and have had for the
month, twenty seven new cases. This is less than we had for the simi-
lar period last year.

Reed and his Board are making most extensive experiments in the
line of Finlay's mosquito theory, and in the line of Reds'eeds preliminary
report. Evidence seems to point very strongly to the mosquito being
the transmitter of the disease. There was so much evidence against
it that I was not at all impressed with the few cases reported in his
original article but his experiments since, have about convinced me.
I think there is no doubt that the mosquito does transmit yellow fever
and the probabilities seem to me that he is the intermediate hostpost. In
case this is proved, the probabilities, I think, would point to the
fact that he is the only means of transmission. This fact establish-
ed, you can see what an important effect it would have upon the sani-
tary measures that would be taken for eradicating the disease. There
are so many points that seem to me contrary to this theory, so many in
my own experience, like the nurses at Las Animas Hospital and the ap-
parent development of fever at isolated points such as those this year
in Mississippi, that I was very averse to receiving the theory, butand a
few absolutely positive experiments outweigh any amount of negative
evidence. So I think if you want to be in at the killing, you had
better come down this winter. I think we are about to make a historic
campaign against yellow jack in Havana next summer, and such a season-
ed old veteran as you ought to have part in such a climax.

I have not included the military in the immigration statistics
because I have not been able to determine a fair estimate for their
numbers. The whole number of troops arriving has not much bearing
upon who remain in Havana. As far as I can find, the new troops were
kept for only a few days at Cabañas and the suburbs of Havana, and
shipped at once to their destinations over the Island. According to
a little work I have, published by a Spanish officer, the garrison of
Havana includesing Guanabacóa and a good many small forts around, not
in the area at present included in Havana, was up to '95, 3,000, in-
creased in '97 to 10,000 and in '98 to 30,000. I think it would be
fair to have this garrison represent the maximum of the non-immune
military population subject to fever in Havana. While they would ra-
pidly acquire immunity, the non-immunes from other garrisons around
the Island coming to Havana on business and pleasure, and the recruits
yearly added to this number to replace men whose service has expired,
will probably keep this garrison with its full quarterquota of non-immunes.
I shall soon be able to speak more definitely on this subject. The
Spanish records give the designation of the commands stationed in Ha-
vana towardduring this time. The records give the names of the commands to
which the men who die in Havana belonged. In this way I can get a
pretty fair idea of what the garrison of Havana furnished. I think
the fairest comparison is the total number of non-immunes. To take
1900 with 30,000 non-immune civilians present and compare it with '97
when there were probably not 2,000 non-immunes present is no basis for
comparison and to likewise take 1900 when there were less than 1,000
soldiers within the limits of Havana, and compare it with '98 when
there were 30,000, is unfair. I will publish the tables under the
head of civil and military with the totals, leaving others to draw re-
ductions. We get our immigration statistics from the books of the
captain of the port previous to 1900, since Bliss has been keeping
them, we have gotten them, from him. I think the disinfection and
isolation has had a very considerable effect in limiting the disease.
You will see that there are a large number of cases in which only one
case occurred in a house and while the majority of the people in most
of these houses were immunes, I think it will be found in the majority
of the cases that there were one or two other non-immunes in the house.
Most of the cases occurred in the person of Spanish servants and very
generally families who keep servants at all have more than one. In
all small stores and bodegas there are several Spaniards.

We expect IreneAilien down for Christmas. Mrs. Gorgas is well and
joins in kindest regards. Plummer, Lyster and Skockley are still in
the office with me and ask to be remembered.
div1.closer: Very sincerely your friend, W. C. Gorgas.
